Introduction

Cutaneous warts are epidermal proliferations caused by human papillomavirus.  The most common presentation is hyperkeratotic papules on the hands and feet of children and young adults.  Spontaneous resolution can occur, but topical treatment (eg, salicylic acid, cryotherapy) is often administered.

Pathophysiology



Cutaneous warts are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), which has many subtypes that have a tendency to infect specific areas of the body and cause distinct disease (eg, HPV 16 and 18 in cervical cancer, HPV 6 and 11 in anogenital warts).  In the case of cutaneous warts, which are located anywhere other than the anogenital area, subtypes 1, 2, and 4 are most commonly implicated.



HPV is usually transmitted via direct contact, although fomite transmission may occur.  The virus enters through small cuts or abrasions and infects basal keratinocytes.  The resulting keratinocyte proliferation leads to the characteristic finding of hyperkeratotic papules.  Lesions can develop weeks to months after initial infection, and malignant transformation is rare.



Histopathologic findings include (

image 1
):



  • Epidermal hyperplasia (acanthosis) with eosinophilic inclusions and keratohyaline granules.
  • Thickened stratum corneum (hyperkeratosis).
  • Dermal papillae enlargement (papillomatosis).
  • Perinuclear cytoplasmic vacuolization (koilocytosis) (
    image 2
    ).

Epidemiology



Infection is most prevalent in children, adolescents, and young adults.  More extensive disease occurs in patients with compromised skin barriers (eg, atopic dermatitis) and cellular immunity (eg, HIV).

Clinical presentation



Cutaneous warts manifest as firm, flesh-colored papules that are rough and hyperkeratotic, often with a cauliflower-like appearance (ie, verrucous) (

image 3
).  Cutaneous warts can occur anywhere on the body, except for the anogenital area since warts in this area are caused by different HPV strains.



Warts on the soles of the feet are referred to as plantar warts, which are usually on pressure points (eg, heel, ball of the foot), whereas those located elsewhere on the body (often hands, fingers, and nailfolds) are called common warts (verrucae vulgaris).  Warts affecting the palms and soles disrupt the normal skin striae, and shaving of the hyperkeratotic area frequently reveals pinpoint bleeding from thrombosed capillaries (

image 4
).



Although most cutaneous warts manifest as verrucous lesions, a less common subtype is flat warts, which are small (1-3 mm), smooth, flesh-colored papules that are most commonly clustered on the face or hands (

image 5
).  Filiform warts are also an uncommon subtype and present as small, narrow, pedunculated lesions (
image 6
).

Differential diagnosis



  • Callus (
    image 7
    ):  These hyperkeratotic areas usually form at bony prominences on the feet or hands in response to repetitive friction.  Calluses present without discrete borders or thrombosed capillaries. 
  • Molluscum contagiosum (
    image 8
    ):  Poxvirus causes molluscum lesions, which present as one or more dome-shaped, smooth, pink, or skin-colored papules with central umbilication.  A rough, dry appearance would not be expected.
  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) (
    image 9
    ):  Herpetic whitlow due to HSV presents acutely with a prodrome of burning/tingling of the finger followed by vesicles on an erythematous base.
  • Lichen planus (
    image 10
    ):  Lesions of lichen planus manifest as flat-topped, polygonal papules or plaques with a violaceous hue.
  • Seborrheic keratosis (
    image 11
    ):  These brown papules or plaques typically develop after age 50 and are well circumscribed with a "stuck-on" appearance. 

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of cutaneous warts is clinical with visualization of single or multiple hyperkeratotic papules.  After paring superficial hyperkeratotic debris, dermatoscopy evaluation revealing small black dots representing thrombosed capillaries supports the diagnosis.



Biopsy is reserved for atypical or refractory cases.

Prognosis and management



Cutaneous warts may resolve spontaneously within 1-2 years in children due to immune clearance; resolution usually takes longer in adults.  Treatment is therefore often initiated due to cosmesis, discomfort, or persistence as well as for those who are immunosuppressed.



First-line treatment of cutaneous warts includes the following:



  • Salicylic acid:  Exfoliates and stimulates local immune response against HPV.  The initial response to treatment may take 2-3 weeks, and complete resolution of the wart may take several months.  Increased effectiveness can be achieved by paring (eg, via pumice stone or nail file) hyperkeratotic lesions prior to medication application and/or applying duct tape over salicylic acid-containing treatment pads.
  • Cryotherapy (eg, liquid nitrogen):  Causes cell damage and leads to an inflammatory response.  Treatment can be painful, and multiple sessions are often required, so this regimen is generally avoided in young children.


Alternative therapies (eg, canthardin, fluorouracil, imiquimod) can be considered for refractory warts.



Despite treatment, recurrence is common.

Prevention



Prevention is primarily achieved by reducing the risk of transmission, such as using protective footwear in public showers.  Limiting avoidable abrasions (eg, due to nail biting) and fomite exposure (eg, others' nail files or towels) can also reduce risk.



Immunization with the HPV vaccine does not reduce risk of cutaneous warts since the strains contained in the vaccine are primarily involved in the development of anogenital warts/cancers as well as head and neck cancers.

Summary



Cutaneous warts (
